title: Agile methodologies explained

details.body:
Agile ways of working include a number of different methodologies, eg Scrum and Kanban. Use whichever methodologies meet the needs of your team.

Meeting the Digital Service Standard

To pass point 4 (use agile methods) in your service assessments, you must show how your team is using agile methods to build and run your service.

Agile terminology

Each methodology has developed its own terminology (or jargon) to describe the tools and techniques it uses. Similar methods may have different names so it’s more important to understand and follow the agile objective of the method, whatever it’s called.

Scrum

Scrum is the most commonly used framework in agile. It provides a highly structured model with clearly defined roles and responsibilities, which can appeal to traditionally structured organisations who are moving to agile.

Detailed guidance on the features of Scrum can be found in the Scrum Guide, written by the developers of Scrum, Ken Schwaber and Jeff Sutherland.

Kanban

Kanban (as a development methodology) was inspired by production systems, like those developed by Toyota, that focus on reducing waste and improving quality.

Kanban focuses on visualising and then improving your current working practices and processes in order to help work flow continuously, quickly and smoothly through your system. A fast, smooth flow of work through your system means you can deliver value quickly and predictably, and can get early feedback to know if you’re providing a product or service that meets your users’ needs.

Read more about Kanban in A brief introduction to Kanban and The Principles of the Kanban Method.

Lean

Lean software development, like Kanban, is adapted from lean manufacturing principles such as the Toyota Production System. The principles behind lean software development focus teams on:

  • reducing waste
  • delivering quickly
  • learning and improving
  • using evidence and data to make decisions

Read more about Lean in The Lean Mindset and The Lean Startup.

Why and when to use Scrum, Kanban and Lean

Scrum

Scrum is a good starting point for teams new to agile working. Teams generally find Scrum most useful when they are:

  • building a new product or service
  • enhancing existing features
  • adding new features in each sprint (a timeboxed period)

When you’re running your live service and have potentially urgent requests you may find sprints constraining. At this stage you may want to move to flow-based working like Kanban. But you can still keep using many of the activities associated with Scrum, like daily stand-ups, retrospectives and regular reviews of progress.

Kanban

Kanban is ideal for teams that want or need to:

  • understand where the bottlenecks are in their processes
  • control the amount of work they’re doing
  • predict their output based on actual delivery

It’s particularly useful when teams need to react quickly to changing priorities.

Lean

Lean provides specific practices and tools that allow teams to focus on learning as quickly as possible. These practices are particularly useful when teams are first discovering what their users’ needs are and when making significant decisions about how to address those user needs.

Related guides

Read the following guides to find out more about working in an agile way:
